title: Acts Chapter 12 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 12 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 12 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 12.

questions.question: Who did King Herod kill with the sword according to Acts 12?
questions.correctAnswer: James the brother of John
questions.explanation: Acts 12:2 states that Herod killed James the brother of John with the sword.

questions.question: Why did Herod proceed to take Peter as well?
options: Because of a command from God
questions.correctAnswer: Because it pleased the Jews
questions.explanation: Acts 12:3 explains that Herod took Peter because he saw it pleased the Jews.

questions.question: Where was Peter put after he was apprehended?
questions.correctAnswer: In prison
questions.explanation: Acts 12:4 says Herod put Peter in prison and assigned soldiers to keep him.

questions.question: What was the church doing for Peter while he was in prison?
questions.correctAnswer: Praying without ceasing
questions.explanation: Acts 12:5 states that the church was praying to God without ceasing for Peter.

questions.question: Who came to rescue Peter from prison?
questions.correctAnswer: The angel of the Lord
questions.explanation: Acts 12:7 describes how the angel of the Lord came upon Peter and helped him escape.

questions.question: True or False: Peter immediately recognized that his escape was real and not a vision.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 12:9 states Peter thought he was seeing a vision and did not initially realize the escape was real.

questions.question: What opened of its own accord to let Peter out during his escape?
options: The iron gate leading to the city
questions.correctAnswer: The iron gate leading to the city
questions.explanation: Acts 12:10 says the iron gate that led to the city opened by itself to let Peter out.

questions.question: After Peter escaped, to whose house did he go?
options: Mary the mother of John Mark
questions.correctAnswer: Mary the mother of John Mark
questions.explanation: Acts 12:12 identifies the house of Mary, mother of John whose surname was Mark, as the place Peter went to.

questions.question: What was the name of the damsel who came to hear Peter knocking?
questions.correctAnswer: Rhoda
questions.explanation: Acts 12:13 states that Rhoda was the damsel who came to listen at the door.

questions.question: True or False: The people immediately believed Rhoda when she told them Peter was at the door.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 12:15 shows that the people thought Rhoda was mad and said it was his angel, not Peter himself.

questions.question: What happened to the soldiers who kept Peter in prison after he escaped?
questions.correctAnswer: They were put to death
questions.explanation: Acts 12:19 says that Herod commanded the keepers to be put to death after Peter's escape.

questions.question: How did the people react to Herod's speech when he was arrayed in royal apparel?
options: They shouted it was the voice of a god
questions.correctAnswer: They shouted it was the voice of a god
questions.explanation: Acts 12:22 records that the people shouted it was the voice of a god, not of a man.

questions.question: What happened to Herod immediately after the people praised him as a god?
options: The angel of the Lord smote him
questions.correctAnswer: The angel of the Lord smote him
questions.explanation: Acts 12:23 describes how the angel of the Lord smote Herod because he did not give glory to God.

questions.question: True or False: The word of God stopped growing after Herod’s death.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 12:24 states that the word of God grew and multiplied despite Herod’s death.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem when they had fulfilled their ministry and took with them ____, whose surname was Mark.
questions.correctAnswer: John
questions.explanation: Acts 12:25 tells us Barnabas and Saul took John, whose surname was Mark, with them.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 12 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 12 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Acts 12 teach us about the power of prayer when facing persecution?
options: Prayer is continuous and fervent among believers
Prayer alone without action is sufficient
Prayer should be done secretly only
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is continuous and fervent among believers
questions.explanation: Acts 12:5 shows that the church prayed without ceasing for Peter's deliverance, illustrating the importance of persistent prayer during persecution. This is supported by verses 12:5, 12:12, and 12:17 which emphasize prayer and thanksgiving.

questions.question: A fellow believer is anxious about being falsely imprisoned for their faith. Based on Acts 12, what biblical truth would you share about God's deliverance?
options: God can send His angel to rescue in miraculous ways
Escape depends solely on human effort
Prison is always permanent for believers
Deliverance is only through political influence
questions.correctAnswer: God can send His angel to rescue in miraculous ways
questions.explanation: Acts 12:6-11 recounts how an angel of the Lord miraculously freed Peter from prison, demonstrating that God's power can intervene supernaturally to deliver His people. This teaches trust in divine rescue amid trials (Acts 12:7, 12:11).

questions.question: What does the reaction of the church to Peter's escape teach about fellowship and encouragement in the body of Christ?
options: The church gathers in prayer and rejoices when God acts
Believers should doubt reports of deliverance
The church discourages sharing good news
questions.correctAnswer: The church gathers in prayer and rejoices when God acts
questions.explanation: Acts 12:12 describes many gathered in prayer at Mary's house, and verses 12:13-16 show their astonishment and eventual joy upon Peter's arrival, emphasizing the importance of fellowship and mutual encouragement in trials.

questions.question: How does Peter's humility after his escape from prison in Acts 12:17 teach us about giving God glory?
options: He quietly shared God's deliverance and left to another place
He boasted publicly about his escape
He blamed others for his imprisonment
He demanded recognition from the church
questions.correctAnswer: He quietly shared God's deliverance and left to another place
questions.explanation: Acts 12:17 shows Peter signaling for silence and calmly recounting how the Lord rescued him, then departing, demonstrating humility and giving God the glory rather than seeking personal praise (Acts 12:17, 12:23).

questions.question: Based on Acts 12, what can we learn about trust and obedience to God's guidance even when the situation seems unreal?
options: Peter followed the angel without fully understanding at first
Peter refused to leave because he doubted
Peter escaped by force without faith
questions.correctAnswer: Peter followed the angel without fully understanding at first
questions.explanation: Acts 12:8-9 shows Peter obeying the angel’s instructions even though he thought it was a vision, teaching us to trust and obey God's leading despite uncertainty (Acts 12:8-10).

questions.question: How does Acts 12 demonstrate the role of God's sovereignty in the midst of human plans?
options: The iron gate opened by itself for Peter to escape
Peter escaped by his own strength
Herod's plans were fulfilled without interference
questions.correctAnswer: The iron gate opened by itself for Peter to escape
questions.explanation: Acts 12:10 describes the iron gate opening on its own as Peter and the angel passed, showing God's sovereign control over circumstances despite human intentions (Acts 12:4, 12:19).

questions.question: What warning does Acts 12 give about pride and giving glory to oneself rather than God?
options: Herod was struck down because he accepted praise as a god
Pride leads to honor from God
God blesses those who exalt themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Herod was struck down because he accepted praise as a god
questions.explanation: Acts 12:22-23 narrates how Herod accepted divine praise and was immediately judged by God, showing the danger of pride and the importance of giving God glory (Acts 12:23).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because their witness seems ineffective. What encouragement can be drawn from Acts 12 about the growth of God's word?
options: The word of God grows and multiplies despite opposition
Only powerful leaders can spread the word
questions.correctAnswer: The word of God grows and multiplies despite opposition
questions.explanation: Acts 12:24 states that despite persecution and trials, the word of God continued to grow, encouraging believers to persevere in sharing the gospel (Acts 12:1-2, 12:24).

questions.question: How does the example of the church’s persistent prayer in Acts 12 encourage us in our personal spiritual discipline?
options: Prayer should be continual and communal in times of need
Prayer is only for private moments
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer should be continual and communal in times of need
questions.explanation: Acts 12:5 and 12:12 show believers praying continuously and together for Peter’s release, teaching the value of persistent, united prayer within the church (Acts 12:5, 12:12).

questions.question: True or False: Herod was pleased to persecute the church because he wanted to please the Jews.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 12:3 states that Herod proceeded to take Peter because he saw it pleased the Jews, showing his motivation to satisfy public opinion through persecution.

questions.question: True or False: Peter immediately recognized that the angel's intervention was real and not a vision.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 12:9 says Peter did not initially understand that what was happening was real; he thought he was seeing a vision until later (Acts 12:9, 12:11).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Acts 12:25, Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem having fulfilled their ______.
questions.correctAnswer: ministry
questions.explanation: Acts 12:25 mentions that Barnabas and Saul returned after fulfilling their ministry, emphasizing faithful service and obedience in church work.

questions.question: How does Acts 12 illustrate the importance of sharing encouraging news within the Christian community?
options: Rhoda ran to tell others that Peter was at the door
Believers kept good news to themselves
News of deliverance was doubted and ignored
Sharing news caused confusion and division
questions.correctAnswer: Rhoda ran to tell others that Peter was at the door
questions.explanation: Acts 12:13-14 describes how Rhoda, upon hearing Peter’s voice, ran to share the news with others, highlighting the joy and encouragement in sharing God's works within the church.

questions.question: What does Herod’s death in Acts 12:23 teach us about the consequences of failing to honor God?
options: God’s judgment comes swiftly on those who do not give Him glory
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment comes swiftly on those who do not give Him glory
questions.explanation: Acts 12:23 shows that because Herod accepted praise as a god and did not glorify God, an angel struck him down immediately, demonstrating divine judgment against pride.

questions.question: How does the sending away of Barnabas and Saul with John Mark in Acts 12:25 teach about teamwork in ministry?
options: Ministry is often fulfilled through cooperative efforts
Only Barnabas and Saul were important workers
John Mark was excluded from ministry
questions.correctAnswer: Ministry is often fulfilled through cooperative efforts
questions.explanation: Acts 12:25 describes Barnabas and Saul returning with John Mark after their ministry, illustrating the collaborative nature of spreading the gospel.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 12 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 12.

questions.question: Who was killed by Herod with the sword as an act of persecution against the church?
questions.correctAnswer: James the brother of John
questions.explanation: Acts 12:2 states that Herod killed James the brother of John with the sword as part of his persecution.

questions.question: What was the significance of the timing when Herod apprehended Peter?
options: It was during the days of unleavened bread
It was during the Feast of Tabernacles
questions.correctAnswer: It was during the days of unleavened bread
questions.explanation: Acts 12:3 specifically notes that Peter's arrest occurred during the days of unleavened bread, indicating the Passover season.

questions.question: How many soldiers were assigned to guard Peter in prison?
questions.correctAnswer: Four quaternions
questions.explanation: Acts 12:4 mentions that Peter was handed over to four quaternions of soldiers, which means 16 soldiers, reflecting Roman military terminology.

questions.question: What continuous action did the church take for Peter while he was imprisoned?
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer without ceasing
questions.explanation: Acts 12:5 emphasizes that the church was earnestly praying to God for Peter's release without ceasing.

questions.question: What unusual event occurred while Peter was sleeping in prison?
options: An angel of the Lord appeared and freed him
A violent earthquake broke the prison walls
Peter had a vision of Jesus
The guards fell asleep and let him escape
questions.correctAnswer: An angel of the Lord appeared and freed him
questions.explanation: Acts 12:6-7 describe how an angel of the Lord appeared, shone light, and liberated Peter by removing his chains.

questions.question: What specific instructions did the angel give Peter after freeing him?
options: Gird thyself and bind on thy sandals; cast thy garment about thee and follow me
Run to the temple and preach immediately
Hide in the city until morning
questions.correctAnswer: Gird thyself and bind on thy sandals; cast thy garment about thee and follow me
questions.explanation: Acts 12:8 records the angel instructing Peter to prepare himself and follow him out of the prison.

questions.question: What was Peter's initial reaction as he followed the angel out of prison?
options: He thought it was a vision
He immediately believed he was freed
He tried to escape through the roof
questions.correctAnswer: He thought it was a vision
questions.explanation: Acts 12:9 shows Peter was unaware that the event was real and thought he was seeing a vision.

questions.question: How did the iron gate leading to the city respond to Peter and the angel?
options: It opened of its own accord
It required a key from the guard
It was broken down by the angel
questions.correctAnswer: It opened of its own accord
questions.explanation: Acts 12:10 describes the iron gate opening by itself as they approached, indicating divine intervention.

questions.question: Where did Peter go after realizing he was free?
options: To the house of Mary, the mother of John Mark
questions.correctAnswer: To the house of Mary, the mother of John Mark
questions.explanation: Acts 12:12 states Peter went to the house of Mary, the mother of John Mark, where many were praying.

questions.question: Who recognized Peter's voice when he knocked at the gate, but did not initially open it?
questions.correctAnswer: Rhoda
questions.explanation: Acts 12:13-14 tells how a young woman named Rhoda recognized Peter’s voice but was so overjoyed she ran in to tell others instead of opening the gate.

questions.question: How did the people inside respond to Rhoda’s claim that Peter was at the gate?
questions.correctAnswer: They said, 'It is his angel'
questions.explanation: Acts 12:15 records that those inside doubted Rhoda and thought she was seeing Peter’s angel, reflecting a belief in guardian angels or visions.

questions.question: What was Herod’s reaction when he learned that Peter had escaped from prison?
options: He ordered the keepers to be put to death
questions.correctAnswer: He ordered the keepers to be put to death
questions.explanation: Acts 12:19 shows Herod’s harsh response: he executed the guards responsible for watching Peter.

questions.question: What event happened to Herod after he gave a public speech and the people acclaimed him as a god?
options: He was struck down by an angel and died
He was overthrown by his guards
questions.correctAnswer: He was struck down by an angel and died
questions.explanation: Acts 12:23 states that because Herod did not give glory to God, the angel of the Lord smote him and he died from being eaten by worms.

questions.question: What happened to the word of God during and after the persecution described in this chapter?
options: It was confined to the church
questions.correctAnswer: It grew and multiplied
questions.explanation: Acts 12:24 affirms that despite persecution, the word of God continued to grow and spread.

questions.question: True or False: Barnabas and Saul took John Mark with them when they returned from Jerusalem after fulfilling their ministry.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 12:25 confirms that Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem and took John Mark along with them.

theological.title: Acts Chapter 12 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 12 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary motivation behind Herod's persecution of the church in Acts 12?
questions.correctAnswer: To please the Jews
questions.explanation: Herod persecuted the church and killed James because he saw it pleased the Jews (Acts 12:3). This reflects the political and social pressures leaders faced, paralleling Pharaoh's opposition to Israel in Exodus 1:10 and the hostility Jesus faced from Jewish leaders (John 11:47-53).

questions.question: Who was killed by Herod with the sword according to Acts 12?
questions.correctAnswer: James the brother of John
questions.explanation: Herod executed James, the brother of John, with the sword (Acts 12:2). This martyrdom echoes the suffering of the early church and the prophetic warnings about persecution (Matthew 10:21-22, Revelation 6:9).

questions.question: How many soldiers were assigned to keep Peter in prison?
questions.correctAnswer: Four quaternions
questions.explanation: Peter was guarded by four quaternions of soldiers, meaning sixteen soldiers (Acts 12:4), highlighting the severity of his imprisonment. This shows the seriousness of Herod's intent, contrasting with God’s sovereign intervention (Psalm 34:7, Daniel 6:22).

questions.question: What was the church doing while Peter was kept in prison?
questions.correctAnswer: Praying without ceasing
questions.explanation: The church was continuously praying to God for Peter’s release (Acts 12:5), exemplifying the biblical doctrine of intercessory prayer (1 Timothy 2:1, James 5:16, Philippians 4:6).

questions.question: What miraculous event enabled Peter's escape from prison?
options: An angel smote Peter and freed him
questions.correctAnswer: An angel smote Peter and freed him
questions.explanation: An angel of the Lord appeared, struck Peter’s side, and caused his chains to fall off, leading to his escape (Acts 12:7). This demonstrates God's sovereignty and his power over imprisonment, similar to the deliverance of Daniel (Daniel 6:22) and the Exodus (Exodus 14:21-22).

questions.question: How did Peter initially react to the angel's rescue?
options: He thought he was seeing a vision
questions.correctAnswer: He thought he was seeing a vision
questions.explanation: Peter did not immediately realize the truth and thought the event was a vision (Acts 12:9), showing human limitations in understanding divine acts, as also seen in visions experienced by prophets (Daniel 10:7-9, Ezekiel 1:28).

questions.question: Where did Peter go after escaping the prison?
options: To the house of Mary, the mother of John Mark
To the mountain outside the city
questions.correctAnswer: To the house of Mary, the mother of John Mark
questions.explanation: Peter went to the house of Mary, the mother of John Mark, where many believers were gathered in prayer (Acts 12:12). This emphasizes the early Christian community's role in prayer and fellowship (Romans 12:4-5, Hebrews 10:25).

questions.question: Who recognized Peter's voice when he knocked at the gate?
questions.correctAnswer: Rhoda
questions.explanation: Rhoda, a servant girl, recognized Peter's voice (Acts 12:13), illustrating the personal relationships within the early church and the power of testimony (Luke 24:34, John 20:16).

questions.question: What was the initial reaction of those inside when Rhoda said Peter was at the door?
options: They reported it to the authorities
questions.correctAnswer: They thought she was mad
questions.explanation: The people inside doubted Rhoda and said she was mad (Acts 12:15), reflecting human skepticism even in the face of miraculous events, similar to the disciples' initial doubt of Jesus' resurrection (Luke 24:11).

questions.question: What was Herod’s punishment for the soldiers who guarded Peter after his escape?
questions.correctAnswer: They were put to death
questions.explanation: Herod had the guards examined and commanded their execution because they failed to keep Peter (Acts 12:19), showing the severity of accountability in leadership and security, paralleling Old Testament laws on responsibility (Exodus 21:14).

questions.question: What was the reaction of the people when Herod made an oration arrayed in royal apparel?
options: They shouted, 'It is the voice of a god, and not of a man'
questions.correctAnswer: They shouted, 'It is the voice of a god, and not of a man'
questions.explanation: The people proclaimed Herod’s voice as divine (Acts 12:22), demonstrating idolatry and false worship, which God judges severely (Isaiah 45:5-7, Romans 1:25).

questions.question: What happened to Herod immediately after the people praised him as a god?
options: He was struck down by an angel and died
questions.correctAnswer: He was struck down by an angel and died
questions.explanation: Herod was struck by the angel of the Lord for not giving glory to God and died from being eaten by worms (Acts 12:23), demonstrating divine judgment against pride and blasphemy (1 Samuel 2:25, Proverbs 16:18, Luke 12:20).

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the word of God growing and multiplying despite persecution?
options: God’s word cannot be hindered by human opposition
Growth depends solely on human effort
questions.correctAnswer: God’s word cannot be hindered by human opposition
questions.explanation: Acts 12:24 states the word of God grew and multiplied, teaching that divine truth advances despite human hostility, echoing Isaiah 55:11, Matthew 16:18, and Romans 8:38-39 about God’s sovereign power and protection over His promises.

questions.question: Who returned from Jerusalem with Barnabas after fulfilling their ministry?
questions.correctAnswer: Saul and John Mark
questions.explanation: Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem with John, surnamed Mark (Acts 12:25), indicating the ongoing missionary efforts in spreading the gospel (Romans 15:20, 2 Timothy 4:11).

questions.question: What does the angel’s intervention in Peter’s escape reveal about God’s nature?
options: God is sovereign and delivers his servants
God is distant from human affairs
God only works through human effort
questions.correctAnswer: God is sovereign and delivers his servants
questions.explanation: The angel’s freeing of Peter (Acts 12:7-10) illustrates God’s sovereignty and providential care over His people, consistent with Psalm 91:11, Daniel 3:28, and Hebrews 13:5, affirming God’s active role in salvation history.
